Her 1989 single, \"Express Yourself,\" was a call to action, urging women not to accept less than they deserve.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1l5kq542","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"wk11w543","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Cyndi Lauper, on the other hand, transformed \"Girls Just Want to Have Fun\" into more than just a party song; it was a joyful scream for autonomy and independence in a world that frequently expected women to conform.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"61bn7545","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"e2c86546","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Mainstream pop is known for love stories and great choruses, but a deeper vision shows bold, enthusiastic lyrics about body confidence, independence, and self-expression. Beyoncé, Ariana Grande, and Lizzo have introduced empowerment into their music, pushing fans, particularly women, to embrace their identities without compromise.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fbts9548","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"1vlg8549","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Their voices do more than just entertain; they inspire. Beyoncé's discography, for example, is filled with themes of strength, motherhood, and resilience. Through songs like \"God Is a Woman,\" Grande promotes spiritual and sexual empowerment. Lizzo's unashamed embrace of body acceptance and self-love defies stereotypes and boosts confidence in listeners from all walks of life.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"9gno1551","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ilz0b552","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Fast forward, and today's pop performers are carrying on that history with vigour. Miley Cyrus explores self-expression and identity, Nicki Minaj deconstructs the double standards surrounding female sexuality, and Dua Lipa promotes confidence and personal independence through songs like \"Don't Start Now.\"","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"j15qp554","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"id":"gcg6k555","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Feminism in Today’s Pop Culture","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700},{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":2,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"g9zeq558","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"la378559","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Modern feminist pop is more than just lyrics; it's about the musicians' life, branding, and activism. Beyoncé's 2016 album Lemonade incorporated deeply personal experiences, cultural commentary, and Black feminist ideology. What was the result? A genre-defining event that resonated with women around the world.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fmtx5561","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"1q6tn562","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In songs like \"No Tears Left to Cry,\" Ariana Grande combines sadness, recovery, and empowerment, while Billie Eilish utilizes her platform to question expectations about how young women \"should\" behave or look.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3myks564","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"h9nwn565","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Other dynamic voices, including Lizzo, Megan Thee Stallion, and Janelle Monáe, continue to redefine pop. They accommodate many body forms, sexual orientations, and cultural backgrounds. They remind us that feminism is not one-size-fits-all; it is as diverse as the women who lead it.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"y7viz567","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"id":"b1vg4568","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Behind the Music: Women Taking Creative Control","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700},{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":2,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6z3mq571","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"gmup7572","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Feminist pop is more than just who sings the song; it's also about everyone who is involved in the production and benefits from it. Artists like Janet Jackson took issues into their own hands. Her 1986 album Control was a declaration of artistic and personal freedom.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"zok8a574","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"c8fwg575","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Tori Amos stepped up to write about things like sexual violence (\"Me and a Gun\") and religious guilt in the 1990s, which many people still avoid discussing today. Around the same time, Alanis Morissette published Jagged Little Pill, which was filled with raw emotion, resistance, and vulnerability.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"8eh24577","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"vepvo578","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Even before then, Annie Lennox was writing, performing, and producing empowering songs like \"Sisters Are Doin' It for Themselves,\" which celebrated women's growing presence in music and culture.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7eob1580","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"0iu84581","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In 2019, Beyoncé became the first Black woman to headline Coachella, transforming the stage into a celebration of Black culture, feminism, and empowerment. Her Homecoming event, which featured over 100 artists and a complete marching band, was more than just a concert; it was a cultural milestone. She paid tribute to historically Black colleges, recognized female trailblazers, and reimagined what pop fame could look like. The world watched in astonishment as music met protest, art met activism. Beyoncé's performance was more than simply entertainment; it was a lesson in how a woman can dominate the world stage unabashedly on her own terms.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"zj9zk583","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"id":"d72jh584","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Global Feminist Pop: Voices Around the World","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700},{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":2,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"sixjf587","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"e0s1w588","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"What began in the United States and the United Kingdom did not end there. Across Latin America, performers such as Karol G and Nathy Peluso are challenging reggaeton's typically male-dominated narrative. Karol G's \"Tusa\" encompasses despair, healing, and empowerment. Peluso's \"Business Woman\" oozes confidence and dares to occupy space unabashedly.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"i6yf1590","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"tbect591","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In South Asia, singers such as Raja Kumari and Priya Ragu are combining ancient rhythms with modern beats to celebrate individuality and oppose patriarchy. Kumari's music embodies pride, perseverance, and intersectionality, whilst Ragu's sound represents the complications of being a South Asian woman traversing two cultures.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ebuvu593","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"efo35594","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In Africa, prominent voices such as Tiwa Savage and Sho Madjozi are redefining what it means to be a female musician on a continent where gender standards are strictly enforced.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"mpqz0596","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"id":"ejx94597","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Final Words","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700},{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":2,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gg7ck600","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ukt9k601","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Feminist anthems in pop music have always been more than just great songs; they are about reclaiming space, changing narratives, and refusing to be silenced. From Helen Reddy's revolutionary roar to today's unapologetic global icons, these songs have carried generations' stories, challenges, and resilience. Moreover, as pop music evolves, so does its ability to inspire change. With every beat, chorus, and verse, one message is clear: women will continue to rise, sing, and form the soundtrack of empowerment for years.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"documentStyle":{}}
Title: Story of Empowerment and Expression Through Feminist Anthems in Pop Music

Plain Content: Punk rock is one of the most popular and unorthodox genres of the twentieth century. Super edgy lyrics, gnarly Instrumentation, and an aggressive stance against the corrupted establishment are the defining characteristics of this genre. The fascinating thing is how effortlessly punk rock was accepted, especially by the youths. Such towering success in resonating with the masses till today after its genesis in the 70s unmistakably reflects the relevance of this genre in our ever-changing society. But what is it about punk rock that makes it so powerful against the system, and why has it endured for nearly five decades? As the title suggests, this article is about the correlation between social degradation, racial discrimination, political disparity, and unforgiving punk rock. To answer these questions, we must look at the roots of punk rock, its key ideologies, and how it continues to inspire generations of individuals who feel disconnected from mainstream society. The Birth of Punk Rock The history of punk rock is one of the streams that originated from a highly influential punk subculture, which includes the history of various punk ideologies, punk visual art, punk literature, fashion, dance, and punk film. Since its emergence in the United States, the United Kingdom, and Australia in the mid-1970s, this subculture has spread around the globe and evolved into a plethora of different forms. If you look at the precursors and the first wave of punk in both the U.S. and the U.K., you will find why this genre became a wildfire and what kindled it. It was the growing sense of frustration with how everything around us was that is the status quo. Additionally, the unabashed glorification of "rockstars" in mainstream rock music or any genre in general, along with overproduced songs and perpetuation of larger-than-life ideologies, when our backyard was on fire, reeled out a direct reaction from the progenitors of punk rock. Early musicians and bands of the genre, such as the Ramones in New York and the Sex Pistols in London, played an integral role in shaping the ethos of punk. Punk stripped rock music down to its raw, rebellious roots. emphasizing short, fast-paced songs, stripped-down instrumentation, and loud, abrasive sound.  The DIY Ethos DIY (Do It Yourself) has always been central to punk rock. Disregarding the necessity of eye-catching, but ostentatious, venue, stage, lighting, and even virtuosity, punk rock bands performed in small pubs or venues where big bands would not. This DIY ethos stood in stark contrast to what was mainstream.  Rebellion Against the System In terms of lyrics, punk rock addressed issues that were often glossed over, if not ignored entirely, by mainstream media; in fact, this was the key factor that made this genre famous among the younger generations. Songs like The Clash’s “London Calling” and Dead Kennedy's “Holiday in Cambodia” tackled themes of political oppression, economic inequality, and social injustice.  Musicians fearlessly pointed fingers at the government and used music as a platform to challenge authority and provoke thought. The confrontational style packed a shockingly powerful punch. However, it was more than just for a shock value, it was a conscious attempt to decimate things that plagued our world and inspire change. Punk Rock in Social Movements Punk rock also stood against societal norms and expectations. Take punk fashion, for example; its aesthetics (ripped clothing, piercings, mohawks, etc), in contradistinction with what is considered normal, declare the rejection of conformity. Thinking for ourselves and questioning the world around us are at the core of the punk subculture. This ethos resonated with marginalized groups, including women and people of color.  The ideologies that punk rock were built upon is surely extreme, but the underlying creeds are quintessential to many other ideologies. Their movements against the system have often coincided with greater social and political movements. The anti-apartheid movement of South Africa and the anti-nuclear movement were supported by bands who advocated for peace and disarmament. Criticism Punk rock has faced numerous criticisms from critics and fans. It is not true for every punk rock band, but the "do it yourself" approach has had many bands delve too much into the raw and rebellious sound at the cost of intricacies that usually make music more interesting. Distortion-imbued raging power chords and fast tempo render their music monotonous and amateurish. A complex and global underground of punks think of anarchism as a proper political ideology, they are sometimes called "peace punks" or "anarcho-punks. They were called on their actions of creating chaos just for the sake of it. These accusations were brought against some punk rock bands as well. Some of them adhere to the belief that violence or property damage is an acceptable way of achieving social change. It is no wonder that punk had many raise their eyebrows at it.   It has also been criticized that the recurring themes of decay, despair, suicide, and social breakdown, as well as the unrestrained emphasis on these, evidentially point toward the nihilism of punk rock. This genre has always aimed at the disillusionment of people. But if the true or, at the very least, better alternative is not presented, such disillusionment is not that useful.  The Legacy of Punk Rock We cannot help but admit that the genre’s DIY ethos has inspired countless musicians, artists, and activists to create their own spaces and paths. Punk rock has taught us to challenge the status quo and not to take the apparent peace granted. Punk rock’s emphasis on individuality and nonconformity is still relevant today. And it would certainly continue to encourage those who feel alienated or oppressed by societal norms. Questioning authority, resisting oppression, and fighting for a better world are still alive in many other genres, and in many ways, it is due to punk rock. From grunge to hip-hop, it has a far-reaching impact. Artists like Nirvana, Rage Against the Machine, and Run the Jewels have drawn inspiration from punk and channeled its spirit through their music. Epilogue  Punk rock’s legacy lives on, and it will live on for centuries to come. It is not confined within the boundary of music anymore, its influence has reached across the broader cultural and political landscape as well. At its core, this genre is more about individualism and self-expression. As long as there are imbalances in the power structure in our world, punk culture will be waging war against it. Until the day when humanity attains the proper peace and harmony, punk rock will remain as a symbol of resistance and resilience.

Distortion-imbued raging power chords and fast tempo render their music monotonous and amateurish.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vi1ia836","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"511l6837","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"A complex and global underground of punks think of anarchism as a proper political ideology, they are sometimes called \"peace punks\" or \"anarcho-punks. They were called on their actions of creating chaos just for the sake of it. These accusations were brought against some punk rock bands as well. Some of them adhere to the belief that violence or property damage is an acceptable way of achieving social change. It is no wonder that punk had many raise their eyebrows at it.  ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"bj8nq839","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"s51w8840","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"huvw3841","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"It has also been criticized that the recurring themes of decay, despair, suicide, and social breakdown, as well as the unrestrained emphasis on these, evidentially point toward the nihilism of punk rock. This genre has always aimed at the disillusionment of people. But if the true or, at the very least, better alternative is not presented, such disillusionment is not that useful. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"sv3q8905","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"style":{},"id":"s79nf843","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Legacy of Punk Rock","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"jqnj6845","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"We cannot help but admit that the genre’s DIY ethos has inspired countless musicians, artists, and activists to create their own spaces and paths. Punk rock has taught us to challenge the status quo and not to take the apparent peace granted. Punk rock’s emphasis on individuality and nonconformity is still relevant today. And it would certainly continue to encourage those who feel alienated or oppressed by societal norms.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gmzel847","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"pjl27848","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Questioning authority, resisting oppression, and fighting for a better world are still alive in many other genres, and in many ways, it is due to punk rock. From grunge to hip-hop, it has a far-reaching impact. Artists like Nirvana, Rage Against the Machine, and Run the Jewels have drawn inspiration from punk and channeled its spirit through their music.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6ecef850","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6azc1851","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"id":"6qfg7852","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Epilogue ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"xft42854","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Punk rock’s legacy lives on, and it will live on for centuries to come. It is not confined within the boundary of music anymore, its influence has reached across the broader cultural and political landscape as well. At its core, this genre is more about individualism and self-expression. As long as there are imbalances in the power structure in our world, punk culture will be waging war against it. Until the day when humanity attains the proper peace and harmony, punk rock will remain as a symbol of resistance and resilience.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"yo20x856","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"documentStyle":{}}
Title: Punk Rock and the Rebellion Against the System

Excerpt: Folk music subscribes to the philosophy that embraces nature and authenticity, and it is not uncommon for folk traditions to be...
Plain Content: Folk music subscribes to the philosophy that embraces nature and authenticity, and it is not uncommon for folk traditions to be associated with rural, rustic, or grassroots forms of art. This could not be further from the truth; historically, it has been a tool for protest and political mobilization.  Rooted in mostly oral traditions, folk songs have narrated histories that were often unwritten, including the grievances of the working class, the pain of war, and resistance to social injustice. Across the 20th and 21st centuries, protest music in the folk tradition has been in line with shifting political consciousness. From labor struggles to civil rights, feminism to climate action, folk protest music has evolved with the spinning wheel of cultural and political sensibility while staying true to its roots. The Origins: Labor, Class, and Early Political Songs In the early 20th century, from the 1900s to the 1940s, the industrialization of the United States ushered in an era of promises and prosperity. But, proving the saying that “there is always a shadow beneath a lamp,” it also gave rise to unprecedented imbalances and inequalities in our social and economic structures. This new era saw the rise of powerful labor movements due to unsafe working conditions, regression, and many more cracks that were appearing in our docile society. What came hand in hand with these protests was the emergence of protest folk songs. These became indispensable tools for solidarity and compassion among working-class communities. The famous “Industrial Workers of the World (IWW),” also known as the Wobblies, is a global labor union that was founded in 1905 in Chicago. Known for its radical but inclusive approach, they advocated for the rights of all workers regardless of skill, race, gender, or origin. They used music as a tool to communicate with workers. As the workers were mostly illiterate, it was an effective method to unite the masses.  The interesting thing about the IWW is their book  “Little Red Songbook” (1909), which is a collection of songs. The songs were composed using known melodies with new radical lyrics. It made them easy to remember and perform in union halls or rallies, or on picket lines. One of the famous martyrs of the movement was folk artist Joe Hill, whose execution in 1915 turned him into a symbol of resistance. His most famous song would be “The Preacher and the Slave,” which ridiculed capitalist promises of "pie in the sky," a term coined by Joe Hill himself. During the Great Depression, the role of folk as the music of survival was being cemented, and Woody Guthrie would perhaps be the most symbolic folk voice of the 1930s and ’40s. His music was able to capture the despair of Dust Bowl migrants. Not only that, the broader discontent with voracious capitalism was also palpable in his music. The 1960s: Protest Folk at the Heart of Culture The 1960s represented a critical turning point. On our way to the modern era, this was the golden period of folk music. It was during this period that folk became both the soundtrack and an active catalyst of revolutions. And no other figure was more influential than Bob Dylan.  He drew from Guthrie and blues traditions and offered his audiences his criticism of war, racial injustice, and generational divides in his own poetic way. Listening to Dylan's songs, such as “A Hard Rain’s A-Gonna Fall” and “Masters of War,” reveals how his music went way beyond simple protest. They invoked systemic criticism.  However, Dylan did not want to remain and be labeled as a “protest singer,” and went electric at the 1965 Newport Folk Festival. It was his signal, or even warning, to his audience that a transformation is ensuing. His move was controversial for sure, but this very move turned his music into protest art from protest music. Folk Decline and Genre Hybridization After the 1960s, protest folk songs somewhat retreated from the cultural forefront. It was partly due to the invasive commercialization of music. The ongoing fragmentation of activists and their movements was also responsible for such fallout. With the end of the gruesome Vietnam War, public disillusionment with institutional politics changed many things. Also, the steep rise of disco and punk took their place, rightfully so, in the pantheon of genres of protest music. Still, protest folk had a long way to go before becoming obsolete, but it survived in hybrid forms. Patti Smith, Bruce Springsteen, and others incorporated folk storytelling into rock. In this interpretation of folk, class struggle and disempowerment played a central role as well. Meanwhile, Ani DiFranco revived the early folk with sharp feminist themes. With her own label, she became an icon of third-wave feminism as well as independent artistry.  Digital Folk and Decentralized Protest In the 2000s and 2010s, folk-infused protest music reemerged but in an entirely new form and context. Artists like Hozier brought moral critiques of religion, homophobia, and colonialism into mainstream pop, which is not only unheard of but also quite extreme. He did this through folk structures and gospel influence. “Take Me to Church” became a viral anthem for LGBTQ+ rights. Meanwhile, Rhiannon Giddens found a way to reconnect folk music to its Black and Indigenous roots. She corrected the misconception that folk is a white genre, which is a huge feat. Her reinterpretations of  “slave songs” and “minstrel tunes” are laudable since they created a bridge that would bring the past to modern justice. Today, Folk protest music is way less centralized, so much so that perhaps it is more democratic. The genre has fragmented into “micro-genres” with different and distinct paths to follow. Yet, what unites all of these is the intent — protest, witness, and critique. A TikTok snippet can now reach millions overnight, achieving the same consciousness-raising impact that once required a concert hall or protest rally. Final Words Historically, folk has always been present in protest songs in one way or another. Folk protest music has reflected and responded to the political landscape of its time. How it evolved from union halls to digital platforms illustrates its adaptability. From labor to liberation, civil rights to climate justice, this genre has remained a witness to collective struggles that changed its tone and platform, but stayed consistent in spirit.

Title: Protest Music In Folk Tradition: From Bob Dylan To Modern Activists

Excerpt: Cheb Khaled is a prominent figure in the world of Raï music and is celebrated across all six continents as a pioneering artist from...
Plain Content: Cheb Khaled is a prominent figure in the world of Raï music and is celebrated across all six continents as a pioneering artist from Algeria. A staggering career that spans for four decades and the worldwide stardom have earned him the befitting epithet "King of Raï." His style of innovative fusion of traditional and contemporary music has caught the attention of critics and the crowd. As his journey with music went on, he started being ubiquitously regarded as one of the greats of contemporary world music who has not only transformed the Raï genre but has also introduced it to an international audience. Cheb Khaled's identity is unimpeachably intertwined with Raï music so much that to understand Khaled as a musician, we need to understand what Raï music is. The word "Raï" was taken from the Algerian Arabic meaning "opinion" or "advice." In the 1920s, Raï music emerged in the Algerian city of Oran—known as “little Paris." In this city, a group of female Muslim singers called Cheikha have abandoned classical poetry and sung in traditional Algerian music. They incorporated pottery drums and end-blown flutes in their songs. They replaced the poetry with lyrics that speak of urban life, portray the struggle of marginalized people, and beg political and religious reformation. In Raï music, one could voice their social and economic dissatisfaction and thus, soon this form of music became a means for breaking out of the shell of ongoing repression. In the 1980s, Raï music was modernized and gained well-deserved global recognition. It was during this period that Khaled was gaining his fair share of well-deserved recognition.       The King of Rai, Cheb Khaled was born on February 29, 1960, in Oran, Algeria, and named Khaled Hadj Ibrahim. By the age of ten, Khaled had already mastered multiple instruments such as the accordion, guitar, and harmonica. He began recording in his early teens under the name Cheb Khaled and by fourteen recorded his first single, “La Route de lycée," thus marking the beginning of his professional career. He was influenced by the eclectic sounds of Oran; this included traditional Algerian music, Western rock, and jazz. The influence of Egyptian, Spanish, and French music should be mentioned here as these played a big part in his identity as a musician. In fact, the monikers "Cheb" and "Chaba" (for female) are used by the later generation of Raï musicians to distinguish themselves from the older generation who used "Cheika" in their name. Although Raï was developed by blending existing rural musical genres and aimed toward the lower class citizens in the 70s, it started morphing into something more global. Khaled was at the epicenter of this fateful revolution and by 1985 his name was practically synonymous to Raï.  Multiple Raï festivals were held in Algeria and beyond the Algerian border; a new wave of music was on its way to shake the world music. Khaled's music gained significant international attraction. His innovative blend of traditional Rai with contemporary instruments and styles brought him admiration and recognition. This succession of serendipitous events eventually earned him the epithet "King of Raï." Khaled has always been aware of his roots, despite the extensive incorporation of elements from Western music in his search for modernized sound. The success of his single "Didi", from his self-titled album Khaled, placed him onto the international stage. Captivating melody, groovy rhythm, and Khaled's mesmerizing voice earned him recognition in Europe and the Middle East. The album, Kutché (1988), had made him well-known in France. But it was his 1992 self-titled album that established his status as an "international superstar." Khaled has sold over 80.5 million albums, so it is not surprising that he holds the Guinness World Record for best-selling artist of raï music. Khaled's lyrics are immaculate works of poetry. Establishing peace and happiness is what he strived for. In his lyrics, he always advocates for peace and unity. Amidst the violence and political unrest during the Algerian Civil War, his music was a symbol of hope. His songs often address themes of love, freedom, and social issues. His words and voice both animate the hopes and struggles of many Algerians. This evocative quality of his creations is relevant even beyond the borders of Algeria. He has become a bridge between Algeria and the world. Khaled is unique in his unconditional passion for music.  Each of his albums is the culmination of his hard work and dedication. Throughout his career, he collaborated with numerous highly acclaimed artists such as Sting and Carlos Santana. During these collaborative endeavors, his passion never dimmed for once. This undying passion has earned him high praise as well as awards. He has received the World Music Award for Best Selling Middle Eastern Artist and the BBC Award for World Music. He is the first Arab singer to win World Music Awards. This is a remarkable story of talent and innovation. From the streets of Oran to the global stage, Cheb Khaled had a remarkable journey. His music resonated with millions of listeners and gave hope and strength. As a true king of music, he broke the barriers and gave people their freedom. He once again showcased the power of music that unites people disregarding the difference in culture and language.
Rich Content: {"nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"foo","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Cheb Khaled is a prominent figure in the world of Raï music and is celebrated across all six continents as a pioneering artist from Algeria. A staggering career that spans for four decades and the worldwide stardom have earned him the befitting epithet \"King of Raï.\" His style of innovative fusion of traditional and contemporary music has caught the attention of critics and the crowd. As his journey with music went on, he started being ubiquitously regarded as one of the greats of contemporary world music who has not only transformed the Raï genre but has also introduced it to an international audience.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"01os5203","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"cpuk6204","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Cheb Khaled's identity is unimpeachably intertwined with Raï music so much that to understand Khaled as a musician, we need to understand what Raï music is. The word \"Raï\" was taken from the Algerian Arabic meaning \"opinion\" or \"advice.\" In the 1920s, Raï music emerged in the Algerian city of Oran—known as “little Paris.\" In this city, a group of female Muslim singers called Cheikha have abandoned classical poetry and sung in traditional Algerian music. They incorporated pottery drums and end-blown flutes in their songs. They replaced the poetry with lyrics that speak of urban life, portray the struggle of marginalized people, and beg political and religious reformation.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"4lzu6206","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"n7cep207","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In Raï music, one could voice their social and economic dissatisfaction and thus, soon this form of music became a means for breaking out of the shell of ongoing repression. In the 1980s, Raï music was modernized and gained well-deserved global recognition. It was during this period that Khaled was gaining his fair share of well-deserved recognition.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0jfwr209","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"     ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"o1bse211","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The King of Rai, Cheb Khaled was born on February 29, 1960, in Oran, Algeria, and named Khaled Hadj Ibrahim. By the age of ten, Khaled had already mastered multiple instruments such as the accordion, guitar, and harmonica. He began recording in his early teens under the name Cheb Khaled and by fourteen recorded his first single, “La Route de lycée,\" thus marking the beginning of his professional career. He was influenced by the eclectic sounds of Oran; this included traditional Algerian music, Western rock, and jazz. The influence of Egyptian, Spanish, and French music should be mentioned here as these played a big part in his identity as a musician. In fact, the monikers \"Cheb\" and \"Chaba\" (for female) are used by the later generation of Raï musicians to distinguish themselves from the older generation who used \"Cheika\" in their name.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"f3kjc213","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"pqe4r214","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Although Raï was developed by blending existing rural musical genres and aimed toward the lower class citizens in the 70s, it started morphing into something more global. Khaled was at the epicenter of this fateful revolution and by 1985 his name was practically synonymous to Raï.  Multiple Raï festivals were held in Algeria and beyond the Algerian border; a new wave of music was on its way to shake the world music. Khaled's music gained significant international attraction. His innovative blend of traditional Rai with contemporary instruments and styles brought him admiration and recognition. This succession of serendipitous events eventually earned him the epithet \"King of Raï.\"","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"hz4v1216","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qxtdw217","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Khaled has always been aware of his roots, despite the extensive incorporation of elements from Western music in his search for modernized sound. The success of his single \"Didi\", from his self-titled album Khaled, placed him onto the international stage. Captivating melody, groovy rhythm, and Khaled's mesmerizing voice earned him recognition in Europe and the Middle East. The album, Kutché (1988), had made him well-known in France. But it was his 1992 self-titled album that established his status as an \"international superstar.\" Khaled has sold over 80.5 million albums, so it is not surprising that he holds the Guinness World Record for best-selling artist of raï music.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1e8cp219","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qshrw220","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Khaled's lyrics are immaculate works of poetry. Establishing peace and happiness is what he strived for. In his lyrics, he always advocates for peace and unity. Amidst the violence and political unrest during the Algerian Civil War, his music was a symbol of hope. His songs often address themes of love, freedom, and social issues. His words and voice both animate the hopes and struggles of many Algerians. This evocative quality of his creations is relevant even beyond the borders of Algeria. He has become a bridge between Algeria and the world.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vrw90222","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Khaled is unique in his unconditional passion for music.  Each of his albums is the culmination of his hard work and dedication. Throughout his career, he collaborated with numerous highly acclaimed artists such as Sting and Carlos Santana. During these collaborative endeavors, his passion never dimmed for once.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"mvai5224","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"LEFT"},"indentation":0}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"e0w00225","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"This undying passion has earned him high praise as well as awards. Title: Icon Of Raï And A Cross-Cultural Bridge: Cheb Khaled

Excerpt: The World Wars took their toll not only on millions of lives and the entire civilisation of the world, but also on the entirety of music...
Plain Content: The World Wars took their toll not only on millions of lives and the entire civilisation of the world, but also on the entirety of music across the globe. The soft, somber, and melancholic music that people cherished and loved in the 1800s was no longer viable. To march the troops on the frontline, to strengthen their bond with their comrades, and to keep them motivated away from home, it demanded a different sort of music. And hence, amongst silence and bombs of war, came the birth of a new song! The Musical Revolution During The World Wars Before the devastating World Wars, classical music and folk music dominated the musical landscape, surpassing all other genres. However, as the war loomed closer, it became apparent that to motivate both the soldiers and common folks. During the time of war, a different approach to music was needed. The Birth Of Patriotic Songs Artists all around the world figured out the appeal of more energetic and patriotic songs during the time of war. Long gone are the days of folk music, during the time of despair, patriotic music is what moved and motivated soldiers to march even to their certain deaths. A few examples of such emotionally driven patriotic music of the World Wars were:  “We Will Meet Again” by Vera Lynn “Imagine Me On The Maginot Line” by George Formby “Kiss Me Goodnight, Sergeant Major” by Arthur Askey “As Time Goes By” by Dooley Wilson Government Investment In The Shift Of the Music Industry As the governments of the conflicted countries soon figured out that patriotic music is helping their soldiers to march despite homesickness. It helps them to sleep despite being afraid to die in their sleep. The government bodies soon started funding artists to make more emotionally expressive songs that would boost the soldiers' morale when on the battlefield. The Exile Of Avant-Garde Artists And Jewish Artists With the shifting tide of the music industry during the World Wars, both the Avant-Garde and the Jewish artists couldn’t quite adapt to the changes. From soft, somber, and soothing folk music to expressive, vigorous, and chivalrous songs was a huge jump in genre that was hard to adapt to. However, the exile of these artists happened due to both the rapid change of the music industry and the shift in world politics. As Nazism grew stronger across Europe, jews were either fleeing the lands or begin prosecuted. Avant-garde artists, on the other hand, were deemed to be politically hindering due to their strong style of lyricism. Hence, along with Jewish artists, avant-garde composers were also prosecuted and their access to the general public through radio and such was reduced. The Rise Of Jazz And Swing Music During The World Wars Not much other genres flourished during the World Wars other than patriotic music, except, of course, “Jazz” and “Swing” music. In war, soldiers experienced a rollercoaster of emotions. From feeling homesick to being demotivated to even being distressed as the war dragged on. The emotionally driven patriotic music did serve its purpose. When soldiers lost all hope and motivation during the days of war as it kept prolonging, such music drove them beyond their limits and helped them march on. However, on the other hand, the soldiers needed to relax and sleep, and remove all the stress they had endured on the battlefield. That is how Jazz and Swing music came in handy. Originating in the early 1900s, jazz music was the perfect mixture of African-American music traditions. They combined the vibes of ragtime, blues, and some European folk music to achieve a perfect blend of harmony. Generally, aimed to be ambiguous and fun to listen to, helping the soldiers on the battlefield to find some ease and enjoyment during the time of war. Swing Music is generally a subcategory of jazz music; however, it is also pretty distinct! Swing music during the early 1900s was aimed to be much like jazz. Fun and relaxing, unconventional lyricism, and rapid innovation were what comprised swing music. The lyricism especially differed a lot from jazz music during the World Wars. Swing music was a vibrant substitute for patriotic music around that time; the lyricism of swing music was generally focused on being engaging and morale boosting for soldiers on the battlefield, while also being vibrant and enjoyable to the ears to relieve them. The Music Industry After The War After 2 hard-fought World Wars, we finally achieved a lasting peace. During the time of the war, the governmental bodies across the globe greatly funded to promote artists who were responsible for the composition of emotionally raw patriotic music. And it was well received by both the soldiers on the battlefield and the general public. Although other variations were also introduced in that period, such as Jazz and Swing music, they were also equally loved by the common public as they were by the veterans. Hence, the music industry didn't just take a turn during the war; rather, it was changed and altered completely, and a new era was ushered in. Technological advancements like radio and the selling of physical copies of records accelerated the growth of these newfound genres of music. In the early days, to become a prominent genre in the world of music, it needed time. However, with such technological advancements, the newly formed genres reached across the globe, door to door, in a matter of a few years. Although patriotic music in general faded away after the time of war, Jazz became a prominent genre in the history of music and is still going strong today! Final Words The two great World Wars surely did change a lot about human civilisation. From changing how we view the world to the entire global infrastructure and economy. In the meantime, it also posed a great change in the music industry. It gave rise to “Patriotic Music” and subsequently to “Jazz” and “Swing” as already discussed. Although two of the genres didn’t find much traction afterwards, Jazz music is still going strong. Music in every era conveys the message of the general people. In the 1900s, it was the message of war, struggle, ptsd, chaos, and of death. It gave birth to new ideas, genres, and artists that inspired generations after to pursue music and make the industry what it is today.

Title: Silence, Bombs, And The Birth Of A New Song

Excerpt: Art, in its myriad shapes and forms, has been with us for millennia, from our caveman days till now. It is the ubiquitous manifestation...
Plain Content: Art, in its myriad shapes and forms, has been with us for millennia, from our caveman days till now. It is the ubiquitous manifestation of the culture we intend to build, the passion we have for ourselves and others, and also the yearning to express oneself, or lack thereof. But in the whirlwind of the 21st century, the tapestry of artistry, particularly in music, has undergone a paradigm shift, which is quite a dramatic one if I may say so. In the past couple of decades, advancements in technology have reshaped industries, businesses, and human behavior in nearly every aspect that we can imagine. Being a musician today entails way more than being good with your voice or your instrument of choice; it means navigating an ever-changing labyrinth of platforms, algorithms, branding, and economic uncertainty. The question that lingers in the minds of both aspiring and established musicians is simple and profound yet terrifying: “Is it still worth it?” To understand the complexities of being a musician in the 21st century is to know how the music scene has evolved over the past decades, the financial and creative challenges musicians face, and whether there is still something organic beneath the digital skin of modern music. The Changing Landscape of the Music Industry The Fall of the Traditional Music Industry Two decades ago, success in music was intimately connected to record deals, physical album sales, radio play, and so on. The Major labels dictated what reached the masses, and artists’ careers were inadvertently curved by contracts under such labels. Now, this model is on the verge of becoming obsolete. The rise of digital platforms has somewhat evened out access to music for musicians and audiences alike. Following “Napster” in the early 2000s came iTunes, and then the floodgates opened for platforms such as Spotify, Apple Music, YouTube, and TikTok. This opening of the floodgate ushered in the era of “streaming culture.” Streaming Culture and Shortened Attention Spans Now, artists can upload tracks from their bedrooms and reach global audiences from their own beds. Such utopian freedom does come with new challenges. Streaming services, while allowing for wide distribution, reduce the value of individual songs. A stream on, say, Spotify earns an artist a mere fraction of a cent. Today, music is something that we “consume,” and most musicians who want to be “successful” are aware of that. So, their music is shaped less by artistic exploration and more by what captures attention quickly. The rise of TikTok has accelerated this, with many songs gaining popularity because of 15-second snippets. These transitions happened really fast and are here to stay, as it seems. So, there has to be an enabler, right? The Algorithm Era Today’s music scene is dominated by a double-edged sword called algorithms. Lesser-known or unknown artists can "blow up" overnight, but it makes the playing field not truly level. Spotify and YouTube push content based on consumers’ behavior and trends. Musicians are often forced to optimize titles, thumbnails, hashtags, and even songwriting structures to appease the algorithmic lords. Isn't it natural to wonder whether a modern musician is still an artist, or a glorified content creator? The Financial Struggles of 21st Century Musicians You might ask, “So what? If musicians can live off of these platforms and there are people who would appreciate their effort, it’s not that bad, is it?” Yeah. But, the thing is… Streaming doesn’t pay enough–plain and simple. Okay, let me rephrase that: “Streaming doesn’t pay enough for everyone.” Among millions of musicians, a select few artists—Taylor Swift, Drake, Ed Sheeran—enjoy global stardom and financial abundance. How do you think the vast majority of musicians are doing financially? Income from physical records is about to vanish, and touring is expensive and grueling. Without relying on side jobs, how will they pay the bills? Artists who used to make a modest but sustainable income through record sales and live shows, the “middle class” of music, have fallen off the wagon, and we didn't notice! Debt, Burnout, and Sacrifice Pursuing a music career is stressful and consumes a substantial amount of resources—money and time. It also involves significant investment in gear, recording, promotion, etc. It is not uncommon for artists to go into debt. Burnout, anxiety, depression and health struggles make it even harder to achieve success. The Passion That Keeps Artists Going The notion of “starving for art” has become an insensitive romanticism. The pressure to maintain an online presence, release content frequently, and engage audiences is relentless. Yet artists persist. Why?  For many, music is not a choice but a compulsion. The act of creation, the connection with audiences, the euphoria of performing on stage—these are deeply fulfilling and cathartic. Musicians find themselves and their sense of purpose during the creative processes of writing, recording, and performing music, even if their bank accounts paint very different pictures. Is Music Still a Creative Endeavor? In music, or any social media platform, to be successful is to go viral. Artists structure songs with catchy rhythms and “hooks” and follow trending sounds. Of course, creativity is involved in how to utilize these tools, however, sadly, it shifts the focus from the neoclassical motto “art for art's sake” to a post-modern one, “art for algorithm's sake.” When an artist writes a song based on what’s trending rather than what they feel, doesn't it raise concerns about authenticity? Some artists now use data analytics to decide what kind of music to make. The choice of genres, tempos, and lyrics—all are based on what’s more likely to go viral. At this point, I think I should clarify that many artists have found a way to blend technology and creativity, and we do see the rise of bedroom producers, indie artists, and experimental musicians whose work is exciting, highly anticipated, and praised for being exceptionally creative. However, there is a common practice of writing songs based on what’s trending rather than what the musician feels, and we cannot call these creative acts; rather, this is just creating content. Redefining Success The music world used to measure “success” by record sales, radio hits, and the number of awards. Now, it is more about the number of monthly Spotify listeners, social media followers, or YouTube views. But in both cases, these numbers don’t always reflect artistic impact, integrity, or ingenuity. Now, artists can redefine success on their own terms. For some, it’s about building a sustainable fan base and living modestly through their music. They can create small but devoted fan bases and find their niche. They can also use the platforms to engage directly with their community. For others, it’s more pushing artistic boundaries or creating music that holds meaning to them. They are concerned less about “monthly listeners” and more about overcoming their own self as a musician. Both of these are equally right paths to walk on. As an artist, you can hop on any one of these boats as long as it nurtures the creative “sapling” inside you. Epilogue: Is It Still Worth It? So, what's the verdict? Is being a musician in the 21st century still worth it? It might depend on how you define "worth." If it’s about financial security or fame, music may be a risky path, and you have to be prepared for a long game. But if it is passion, impact, and creative fulfillment, music still has something profound and meaningful to offer. For those who want to pursue music, knowing all of the things we touched on, the answer is “always yes.”

Musicians find themselves and their sense of purpose during the creative processes of writing, recording, and performing music, even if their bank accounts paint very different pictures.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":16}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"poqsc2519","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"style":{},"id":"2n0n71038","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Is Music Still a Creative Endeavor?","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ihvki1040","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"8i5k82598","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In music, or any social media platform, to be successful is to go viral. Artists structure songs with catchy rhythms and “hooks” and follow trending sounds. Of course, creativity is involved in how to utilize these tools, however, sadly, it shifts the focus from the neoclassical motto “art for art's sake” to a post-modern one, “art for algorithm's sake.”","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":16}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"q4vd71042","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"jz2nz1043","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"When an artist writes a song based on what’s trending rather than what they feel, doesn't it raise concerns about authenticity? Some artists now use data analytics to decide what kind of music to make. The choice of genres, tempos, and lyrics—all are based on what’s more likely to go viral.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":16}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"v09r51045","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"juhw91046","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"At this point, I think I should clarify that many artists have found a way to blend technology and creativity, and we do see the rise of bedroom producers, indie artists, and experimental musicians whose work is exciting, highly anticipated, and praised for being exceptionally creative. However, there is a common practice of writing songs based on what’s trending rather than what the musician feels, and we cannot call these creative acts; rather, this is just creating content.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":16}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"57crj1048","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"id":"od5171049","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Redefining Success","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"js01r1051","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"gkuhr2806","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The music world used to measure “success” by record sales, radio hits, and the number of awards. Now, it is more about the number of monthly Spotify listeners, social media followers, or YouTube views. But in both cases, these numbers don’t always reflect artistic impact, integrity, or ingenuity.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":16}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"t5dpz1053","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Now, artists can redefine success on their own terms. For some, it’s about building a sustainable fan base and living modestly through their music. They can create small but devoted fan bases and find their niche. They can also use the platforms to engage directly with their community.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":16}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"mqnza1055","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"7gjk41056","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"For others, it’s more pushing artistic boundaries or creating music that holds meaning to them. They are concerned less about “monthly listeners” and more about overcoming their own self as a musician. Both of these are equally right paths to walk on. As an artist, you can hop on any one of these boats as long as it nurtures the creative “sapling” inside you.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":16}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"5kpab3119","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"1lcn91058","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Epilogue: Is It Still Worth It?","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"xtfpv1060","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"zkxyd2986","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"So, what's the verdict? Is being a musician in the 21st century still worth it?","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":16}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"0k2e71062","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"It might depend on how you define \"worth.\" If it’s about financial security or fame, music may be a risky path, and you have to be prepared for a long game. But if it is passion, impact, and creative fulfillment, music still has something profound and meaningful to offer. For those who want to pursue music, knowing all of the things we touched on, the answer is “always yes.”","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":16}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"documentStyle":{}}
Title: Being an Artist In The 21st Century: Is It Still Worth It?

Excerpt: On a quiet afternoon, if anyone strolls through the corridors of Lahore’s Sanjan Nagar Institute of Philosophy and Arts,  they might come...
Plain Content: On a quiet afternoon, if anyone strolls through the corridors of Lahore’s Sanjan Nagar Institute of Philosophy and Arts,  they might come across something remarkable; something that is both modern and ancient at the same time; something that can create extraordinarily delicate and flowing sounds. This “ thing ” is Sagar Veena , a musical instrument unlike any other. Sagar Veena  is a mesmerizing instrument that can bring the boundlessness of our imagination to life. Unbound by the limitations of time or space, it was designed to reestablish and reimagine the spiritual depth of South Asian  classical music.  An even more unique fact associated with this instrument is that there is only one performer in the world, Noor Zehra Kazim , daughter of the visionary thinker and lawyer Raza Kazim , who is the inventor of this instrument. This is an article on a father-daughter duo who have developed a rare musical legacy that is an immaculate bridge between innovation and tradition, sound and silence, east and west. Origins: An Intellectual and Artistic Quest The story of the Sagar Veena  begins in the mind of Raza Kazim , a lawyer, philosopher, politician, and polymath. He was one of the prominent political figures in Pakistan ’s early days. However, as he grew more and more disillusioned with politics, he progressively became a dissident thinker. In the 1970s, this disillusionment is what eventually made Kazim  turn his attention to other things he was drawn to; one of those was music. Through his research on how instruments across cultures are built, tuned, and heard, he realized the instruments of South Asia  are becoming too mechanical and homogeneous despite having such a rich culture to draw from. At this moment, he began to form the concept of an instrument that would inherit the subtlety of ancient veenas  and at the same time, it would be compatible with the modern sensibility of North Indian  classical music (NICM). A New Voice for an Ancient Tradition. The name is divided into two parts; “ Sagar ” is a Sanskrit word for ocean, and “ Veena ”is a generic term used to classify the family of stringed instruments which closely resemble lutes. It is the outcome of dynamic experimentations carried out by Raza since 1970 with the cooperation of his daughter, Noor Zehra , in practically testing the potential of the instrument as a serious musician. Veenas can be both fretted and fretless. The Sagar Veena  is fretless, which allows for a fluidity of sound that enables the performer to explore microtonal slides and intricate ornamentations. Sagar Veena  has two gourds, and this is quite a departure from all existing stringed instruments of NICM, in all respects. In the Sagar Veena , the main players are not the obvious, tangible, or measurable aspects of sound–the pitch or the volume, for example—but rather the intangible characteristics such as timbres, resonances, and harmonics, and a wide range of them. Noor  shared in an interview, "The aim was to create an instrument that could explore the tonal subtleties lost over centuries. The sound had to be intimate, deeply personal, and spiritually invoking." The Lone Performer: Noor Zehra Kazim "When I began playing the Sagar Veena, it wasn’t just about learning an instrument—it was about learning how to listen in a different way” — Noor Zehra Kazim Noor Zehra Kazim  was surrounded by philosophy, literature, and the arts from a young age. But it was music that enchanted her the most. Kazim then went to Berkeley, California in the US, and there she studied at the “ Ali Akbar College of Music .” She learned under Ustad Shareef Khan Poonchwala  for a few years in Pakistan , and she became well known as the only Veena player of Pakistan . Noor Zehra  has played the Sagar Veena  for countless audiences, and has even travelled to Japan and Norway for performances. Being the only player of an instrument entails both immense responsibility and artistic solitude. Unlike other instrumentalists, she does not have any legacy of recordings to learn from and no master to correct her form. Every raga she performs is shaped through intuition, long hours of practice, and her own evolving understanding of sound. Not Just an Instrument—A Philosophy “In a way, the Sagar Veena plays me.” — Noor Zehra Kazim 				 The Sagar Veena  is built on the philosophy of listening and composing. It holds a significant place in a broader intellectual movement fostered by Raza Kazim  through his Sanjan Nagar Institute of Philosophy and Arts (SNIPA) .  Sagar Veena  stands for the research in sound, music theory, and aesthetics, concepts that are central to SNIPA ’s creed. Sagar Veena is not merely played; it is rethought constantly. Noor Zehra ’s involvement in this is more like a researcher. She records her sessions, analyzes, and often reconfigures her own playing techniques. In fact, more than seventeen Sagar Veenas have been made since its inception. Why Does It Matter? Sagar Veena  goes against commercialization and dwells in obscurity. These two factors make Sagar Veena  an outcast yet unique instrument, especially for not entertaining the race of mass production, both in form and philosophy.  A profound effect is how it invites to redefine what it means to be a musician. For Noor Zehra , being a musician is not about display or virtuosity, but about being a channel through which the sound can travel. Looking Ahead: Will the Sagar Veena Survive? “What happens when Noor Zehra  stops playing?” is a natural question that can pop up in anyone's head. The truth is, so far, no new performer has emerged. Which is understandable since the technique is complex, the training demanding, and the path too isolated for many. Both Noor  and Raza Kazim  are not concerned with such poignant speculations. To them, what matters is not permanence, but the kind of listening it enables. Epilogue: A Sound Beyond Time “The Sagar Veena is not a loud instrument, but it speaks volumes.” In our noisy world, the Sagar Veena  is a whisper that is impossible to ignore. It is music not just for the ears, but for the soul. It forces the listeners to pause, to reflect, and to hear again what they often forget. The history that the Sagar Veena  shoulders is of solitude, invention, and authenticity. We might not witness anyone taking up the Sagar Veena  after Noor Zehra , and it would not even matter. What Noor  is leaving behind has the potential to sprout into something more valuable and significant; that is the true legacy of Sagar Veena.
