Title: Blues, Jazz, and the Roots of Black Resistance

Excerpt: Originating in Jamaica in the late 1960s, reggae has been a sharp voice raised against colonialism and imperialism from its birth. It...
Plain Content: Originating in Jamaica in the late 1960s, reggae has been a sharp voice raised against colonialism and imperialism from its birth. It emerged from the struggles of communities in the Afro-Caribbean and became the very soundtrack of anti-colonialism across Africa and the Caribbean. The wave of reggae swept over South Africa as well, in fact, the rhythmic and thematic aspects of reggae are strongly associated with Africa, so much so that it has been called "the quintessential African musical form".  In the African and, also, in the global music scene, South African reggae musician and Rastafarian Lucky Dube is venerated as a pioneering musician of this genre. He is one of the best selling African musicians, and his music has always been the embodiment of the soul-piercing nature of reggae. This article will take you through the chronicles of Dube's life—from his birth to his ascension to the throne. Early Life: Roots & Struggles Born into a Zulu family at a farm on the outskirts of Ermelo, a small town in the west of Johannesburg, Dube grew up with his grandmother since his mother had to move from place to place in search of a job. He credited his grandmother for being the one who made Dube the person he was.  The son of a Zulu mother and an estranged father from the Swazi ethnic group, Dube's early life was harsh. The unforgiving realities of apartheid, racial segregation, and discrimination enforced by the government had marginalized South Africans to a horrifyingly extreme degree. He had to go through poverty and starvation as food was often extremely rare. To sustain themselves, Dube and his two siblings fed on the soup made by their grandmother from sheep's droppings. Musical Beginnings and Breakthrough The macabre grip of the apartheid era made Dube experience firsthand how everyone around him was deprived of opportunities and economic stability. So, when he was working as a gardener in his early years, he attended Jan Rell High School, where he formed the Skyway Band, his first musical ensemble.  In 1983, Dube moved to Madadeni, a township on the outskirts of Newcastle, and joined "the Love Brothers". This group was led by his cousin and performed in the mbqanga, a style that blends soul and pop with traditional Zulu music. He released multiple albums with this group and his cousin, such as "Lucky Dube and the Supersoul,"  a Afrikaans album "Die Kaapse Dans" in the Afrikaans language, and the EP "Help My Krap". All these records were gaining traction among his native audiences.  Rise to Fame and Musical Evolution In his school years, Dube became aware of Rastafari, an Abrahamic religion that developed in Jamaica during the 1930s. It was a response to colonialism. Also, systemic oppression and racial inequality were brought along with it. Reggae became a form of expression of Rastafarian spirituality. Dube did not consider himself a Rasta in the traditional sense; he only embraced aspects of the faith, such as vegetarianism.  Dube noticed that his reggae songs resonated with his audience during concerts and realized the potential impact reggae might have in the sociopolitical commentary of South Africa. With that in mind, in 1984, he released the first reggae album, "Rastas Never Die". Unfortunately, this mini album did not perform well and was banned by the regime due to its critical lyrics. But Dube was indomitable; he kept on performing the reggae tracks live and released a second reggae album, "Think About the Children," in 1985. This time, it did not miss the mark and achieved Platinum sales status. His sophomore album established Dube as a popular reggae artist in South Africa and caught the eyes of people outside his homeland.  Reggae: A Tool for Change Dube's incorporation of African rhythms and reggae became his trademark, recognized by audiences both in his country and abroad. His adoption of reggae was not accidental; rather, he had a clear and stern reasoning behind it. Much like Marley, Dube used his music as a platform to speak out against the injustices faced by South Africa’s black majority. One of his most famous songs, "Together As One",  yearns for unity amidst division and segregation. Other songs, such as "House of Exile" and "Different Colours, One People", strongly inherit the essence of Dube's music and philosophy. His immaculate storytelling upholds the necessity of racial harmony and equality and was propelled by his personal experiences under apartheid. Global Recognition of a Pioneer Dube's international recognition and success were merely a matter of time. One after another, he was putting out albums that brought in both popularity and money. He became a household name with the release of "Slave" in 1987. Two years later, he released his double-platinum album "Prisoner". Shortly after, he started performing in Europe and the US for the first time. He was the first South African artist to appear at Jamaica's Reggae Sunsplash. The performance and the stage presence he showcased in these concerts resulted in a headline spot for the international segment of the following year's event. His reputation as a musical pioneer was known by the whole world, and he had broken through the barriers of race and geography by this time.  The Twist of Fate Lucky Dube's life was tragically cut short on October 18, 2007. A musician, who was walking tirelessly on his path of regaining freedom and justice for his people, was murdered in a carjacking incident in a suburb of Johannesburg, Rosettenville. The shockwaves were felt throughout the music world, and his passing left a void in the hearts of millions of fans worldwide. Epilogue  Lucky Dube was recognized not only for his exceptional musical talent but also for his role in promoting peace, unity, and social justice through his art. In remote Aboriginal communities of Australia, he is known for being "Bigger than the Beatles". It would be an understatement to call him a global star. Only those who have been touched by Dube's unfiltered raw emotions can feel it in their soul what Lucky Dube was. The empty throne that he left would surely find another worthy king who would bear Dube's legacy on their shoulders. He once sang, "The truth is an offense, but not a sin." Lucky Dube's truth will keep on resonating and inspiring new generations to carry the torch of freedom and equality.

The wave of reggae swept over South Africa as well, in fact, the rhythmic and thematic aspects of reggae are strongly associated with Africa, so much so that it has been called \"the quintessential African musical form\". ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"i9pf8393","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"kvn8f394","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In the African and, also, in the global music scene, South African reggae musician and Rastafarian Lucky Dube is venerated as a pioneering musician of this genre. He is one of the best selling African musicians, and his music has always been the embodiment of the soul-piercing nature of reggae. This article will take you through the chronicles of Dube's life—from his birth to his ascension to the throne.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"7yhne396","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Early Life: Roots & Struggles","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"uld85398","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Born into a Zulu family at a farm on the outskirts of Ermelo, a small town in the west of Johannesburg, Dube grew up with his grandmother since his mother had to move from place to place in search of a job. He credited his grandmother for being the one who made Dube the person he was. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"fyqxo400","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"1vhb9401","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The son of a Zulu mother and an estranged father from the Swazi ethnic group, Dube's early life was harsh. The unforgiving realities of apartheid, racial segregation, and discrimination enforced by the government had marginalized South Africans to a horrifyingly extreme degree. He had to go through poverty and starvation as food was often extremely rare. To sustain themselves, Dube and his two siblings fed on the soup made by their grandmother from sheep's droppings.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"mwy5y403","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Musical Beginnings and Breakthrough","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"2a14g405","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The macabre grip of the apartheid era made Dube experience firsthand how everyone around him was deprived of opportunities and economic stability. So, when he was working as a gardener in his early years, he attended Jan Rell High School, where he formed the Skyway Band, his first musical ensemble. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"gat08407","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"eyv0h408","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In 1983, Dube moved to Madadeni, a township on the outskirts of Newcastle, and joined \"the Love Brothers\". This group was led by his cousin and performed in the mbqanga, a style that blends soul and pop with traditional Zulu music. He released multiple albums with this group and his cousin, such as \"Lucky Dube and the Supersoul,\"  a Afrikaans album \"Die Kaapse Dans\" in the Afrikaans language, and the EP \"Help My Krap\". All these records were gaining traction among his native audiences. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"6wl3q410","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Rise to Fame and Musical Evolution","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"gtiyn412","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In his school years, Dube became aware of Rastafari, an Abrahamic religion that developed in Jamaica during the 1930s. It was a response to colonialism. Also, systemic oppression and racial inequality were brought along with it. Reggae became a form of expression of Rastafarian spirituality. Dube did not consider himself a Rasta in the traditional sense; he only embraced aspects of the faith, such as vegetarianism. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"n74ye414","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"8qejz415","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Dube noticed that his reggae songs resonated with his audience during concerts and realized the potential impact reggae might have in the sociopolitical commentary of South Africa. With that in mind, in 1984, he released the first reggae album, \"Rastas Never Die\". Unfortunately, this mini album did not perform well and was banned by the regime due to its critical lyrics.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"iatkk417","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"w7obm418","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"But Dube was indomitable; he kept on performing the reggae tracks live and released a second reggae album, \"Think About the Children,\" in 1985. This time, it did not miss the mark and achieved Platinum sales status. His sophomore album established Dube as a popular reggae artist in South Africa and caught the eyes of people outside his homeland. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vsm0c420","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"id":"wt7j8421","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Reggae: A Tool for Change","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"dn3jq423","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Dube's incorporation of African rhythms and reggae became his trademark, recognized by audiences both in his country and abroad. His adoption of reggae was not accidental; rather, he had a clear and stern reasoning behind it. Much like Marley, Dube used his music as a platform to speak out against the injustices faced by South Africa’s black majority.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6r335425","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"wgeut426","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"One of his most famous songs, \"Together As One\",  yearns for unity amidst division and segregation. Other songs, such as \"House of Exile\" and \"Different Colours, One People\", strongly inherit the essence of Dube's music and philosophy. His immaculate storytelling upholds the necessity of racial harmony and equality and was propelled by his personal experiences under apartheid.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"1z2k4428","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Global Recognition of a Pioneer","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"wyknq430","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Dube's international recognition and success were merely a matter of time. One after another, he was putting out albums that brought in both popularity and money. He became a household name with the release of \"Slave\" in 1987. Two years later, he released his double-platinum album \"Prisoner\". Shortly after, he started performing in Europe and the US for the first time. He was the first South African artist to appear at Jamaica's Reggae Sunsplash.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"jqrl1432","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"deea3433","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The performance and the stage presence he showcased in these concerts resulted in a headline spot for the international segment of the following year's event. His reputation as a musical pioneer was known by the whole world, and he had broken through the barriers of race and geography by this time. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"hrlvt435","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Twist of Fate","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"15uzh437","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"oc9g4438","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Lucky Dube's life was tragically cut short on October 18, 2007. A musician, who was walking tirelessly on his path of regaining freedom and justice for his people, was murdered in a carjacking incident in a suburb of Johannesburg, Rosettenville. The shockwaves were felt throughout the music world, and his passing left a void in the hearts of millions of fans worldwide.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1trnh440","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"id":"7pank441","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Epilogue ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"20fdz443","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Lucky Dube was recognized not only for his exceptional musical talent but also for his role in promoting peace, unity, and social justice through his art. In remote Aboriginal communities of Australia, he is known for being \"Bigger than the Beatles\". It would be an understatement to call him a global star. Only those who have been touched by Dube's unfiltered raw emotions can feel it in their soul what Lucky Dube was. The empty throne that he left would surely find another worthy king who would bear Dube's legacy on their shoulders. He once sang, \"The truth is an offense, but not a sin.\" Lucky Dube's truth will keep on resonating and inspiring new generations to carry the torch of freedom and equality.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7c4xy445","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"documentStyle":{}}
Title: Lucky Dube: Resistance and Reggae

Excerpt: Music is akin to a mirror to society, culture, and ideology which reflects the engraved joys, struggles, and revolutions. It has never...
Plain Content: Music is akin to a mirror to society, culture, and ideology which reflects the engraved joys, struggles, and revolutions. It has never been a mere medium for entertainment; the hopes, dreams, and even regrets of the masses are what drives musicians in making music and draws people. However, for many artists, such an act of creating music becomes the catalyst that forces them into exile and leave their country and their people. To escape persecution, unethical censorship, or violence, musicians often move beyond borders, and many of them end up reshaping their lives and career by channeling personal loss into songs which eventually become anathematic to revolution and resistance. Their stories reveal the crux of indomitable urge of  creating a piece of art; and that is “art survives everything.” It is fascinating how exile redefines someone's identity, and how melodies possess uncanny ability to shake the foundation of authoritarian regimes.  This article dives into the lives of musicians in exile, how it influences their craft, brings in substantial changes in their homeland’s cultural landscape, and tears down fallacious political narratives. Fleeing Homelands Amidst Turmoil Being exiled is almost never a choice for anyone. Riddled by incessant political misappropriation and ruthlessly oppressive regime, musicians unwillingly leave their own home and settle in a foreign country. In most of the cases, they are left with no other options since their music has become a liability.  Take the example of Victor Jara, a Chilean director, poet, singer-songwriter and political activist. His works are quintessential in developing Chilean theater and his music   became synonymous to Salvador Allende’s socialist movement in the 1970s. Gos songs became synonymous with Salvador Allende’s socialist movement in the 1970s. Following the coup of Augusto Pinochet that toppled the government, Jara was assassinated for his music’s political potency. In Iran, music is heavily censored, so much that to thrive the underground rock scene has to operate in secrecy. Iranian artist Mohsen Namjoo, who is known as “the Bob Dylan of Iran,” and whose music is a unique blend of ancient and contemporary sounds, was arrested for blending Persian poetry with bluesy critiques of theocracy. After being charged with “insulting Islamic sanctities” in 2009, Namjoo fled to Europe, where he continues to produce music banned in his homeland. While we are at it, I would like to mention another musician, Masha Alekhina of the Russian punk collective Pussy Riot, who kind of represents a generation of Russian artists who have fled abroad to escape imprisonment for challenging Vladimir Putin’s regime. In April 2022, she fled the country disguised as a delivery driver after the announcement of her sentence to time in a penal colony. The Sound of Displacement All three of the stories that we came across so far do have one common thing among them. It is the hypersensitivity to criticism. Paired with insatiable greed for power of government. This is usually the primary factor for most of the cases of exiling. Governments equate music with subversion, thus for a musician exile becomes the price of truth-telling. Cut off from their roots, musicians deal with nostalgia for their country apart from alienation in their new home. For these reasons, they feel the urgent need to redefine their place in the world. This often ignites and fuels an artistic evolution. In a way, exile fractures identity. For “Fela Kuti”, Nigeria’s Afrobeat pioneer, exile was crucial. After releasing "Zombie"(1976), where he critiques Nigeria’s military government, soldiers raided his commune, beat him and threw his mother from a window. Fela had to flee to Ghana but returned months later, his music fiercer and more politically charged. His sound—a fusion of jazz, funk, and Yoruba rhythms—had become a weapon, inspiring pan-African solidarity.   In Fela's case, being exiled had created hybridity. However, in contrast, Syrian pianist “Malek Jandali” took his exile as an opportunity to preserve cultural heritage. Born in the “capital of revolution,” Homs, Syria, which was one of the worst-hit areas during the three-year Syrian conflict. Surviving a 2011 attack, Jandali relocated to the U.S. His music reimagines ancient Syrian melodies with orchestral grandeur. It is his personal grief and a plea for peace.      But, unfortunately not all transformations are redemptive. Many artists lose their career and identity after being exiled in a foreign country. Even if they made a name for themselves again, their music becomes a dialogue between memory and reinvention—a search for belonging in the dissonance. As Cuban legend “Paquito D’Rivera,” who defected to the U.S. in 1981, described exile as a “spiritual amputation.”   Reshaping a Nation’s Musical Identity Exiled musicians rarely fade into silence. Rather, their work often transcends borders which influences not only the country they reside in, but also their homeland’s cultural trajectory from afar.  Artists are always more sensitive to their inner self as well as their environment. If exiled, it can only be imagined how deeply they might experience every emotion from fear to sadness. They cannot ever sever their ties with their homeland and their people. They still feel the need to do something for their fellow countrymen. Following the ban of “Miriam Makeba” by South Africa’s apartheid regime in 1960 for testifying against it at the UN, she became a global icon. It was quite the opposite of what the oppressive regime wanted or anticipated. Her hits like Pata Pata  introduced the world to African rhythms, while her activism kept horrors of apartheid regime in the spotlight for every pair of eyes of the world to see. Though banned from her country for three decades, Makeba’s music kindled and supported the anti-apartheid movement, proving that exile could amplify a message rather than stifle it. Epilogue: The Unsilenced Exiled musicians are more than refugees—they are archivists of memory and they have an immaculate ability to fight their trauma, and be the architects of change. The said change is not necessarily for their own sake, in majority of the cases, it is for the sake of their people, and their collective hopes and dreams.  Their songs are the touchstones, forged in the crucible of displacement, that challenge the notion that mere borders can contain ideas. From Fela Kuti’s defiant and raucous music to the whispered tone of underground Syria ballads, their music transcends geography, turning exile into a bridge between the silenced and the free.

Title: Songs Behind Silence: Musicians in Exile

Excerpt: " If there’s no caste in birth, where does it come from?" – Lalon Shah The path of Sufism is rooted in love, humanism, and unity. It has...
Plain Content:
" If there’s no caste in birth, where does it come from?" – Lalon Shah The path of Sufism is rooted in love, humanism, and unity. It has been an integral part of Bengali culture and spirituality despite being linked to Persian and Arabic traditions. Sufism even took on a unique regional form in Bengal, which is distinctly local yet universal in many ways. 
 Among the most prominent figures who hailed from this region was Lalon Shah, who embodied the fusion of mysticism and music, and at the same time preached the reformation of both soul and society. Lalon Shah, or Lalon Fakir, is a 19th-century spiritual leader, philosopher, mystic poet, and bard whose songs continue to be an inseparable part of  rural Bengal. 
 The songs of Lalon aim at an indescribable reality way beyond realism. He spoke of what he  observed; he spoke of day-to-day problems in simple yet moving language. This article is all about Sufism and Lalon Fakir, and how his music and philosophy influenced the structure of Bengali culture. 
 The Rise of Mystical Thought in Bengal Culturally, Bengal had a rich confluence of Hindu, Buddhist, Islamic, and tribal cultures which set the stage for a mystical and spiritual tradition like Sufism. But, by the 18th and 19th century, under colonial rule, big changes were about to come in. During this time, Bengal was undergoing great political, religious, and social shifts. And Lalon emerged from this complex landscape, but not from some scholarly or aristocratic family, rather from a community where oppression, discrimination, and poverty were realities. 
 Mystical traditions in Bengal often blurred the boundaries between religious identities. Sufi saints, Bauls (wandering minstrels), and Bhakti poets all contributed to a somewhat singular tradition where inner devotion is the priority, not ritual. In their mind, human equality was more desirable than hierarchy. Lalon inherited the essence of Baul and Sufi traditions and turned them into songs with deep and philosophical lyrics. 
 Lalon’s Life and Mystical Awakening Lalon Shah’s early life shares a similarity with his music and philosophy—mystery. His earlier years are shrouded in legend. On one hand, some accounts say he was born a Hindu where others claim he was a Muslim. However, what is generally accepted is that he fell seriously ill once, during a pilgrimage. His companions left him behind but a muslim family rescued him and nursed him back to health. This event became the point where Lalon came face to face with the contrived and phoney boundaries that society and religion have created. 
 Returning home, Lalon was met with rejection by his community for living in a muslim house. This ostracization finally broke the barrier down for him. After that he never went back to any fixed religious identity. He had the calling of universal mysticism and embraced it. He settled in Kushtia, where he established an Akhra —a spiritual and cultural space where music, philosophy, and social reflection thrived. 
 The Core of Lalon’s Sufi Philosophy In Lalon's mind spirituality and humanity both are different sides of the same coin. His songs resonate with this philosophy and, so, these songs sound deeply spiritual yet humanistic. He often explored the idea that the divine is present within the human being. He takes the “self” as the key to understanding the divine. In his world, the dichotomy between the material and the spiritual, and between the body and the soul do not exist. 
 Through questions, Lalon tore off the ostentatious veil of organized religion. He exposed the hypocrisies of society and religion as well as the ploy to divide and control people. Lalon emphasized love, tolerance, and wisdom; Lalon rejected blind adherence to scripture. His songs challenged both Hindu Brahmins and Muslim clerics. Lalon was non-sectarian in this regard. 
 Music as Medium of Protest and Reform Lalon was unbiased in terms of both compassion and critiquing religion. Every religion, every organization and every human were the same in his eyes. And his music reflects that , and that is why Lalon songs are widely popular among both Hindu and Muslim communities due to their non-sectarian spirits and universal urge. 
 Such inclusiveness was bound to make his music a powerful tool for social critique. During British colonialism, when caste-based discrimination and communalism were rising, Lalon's songs were the counter-narrative for human dignity. 
 He sang in the language of the common people of rural Bengal which ensured that his messages reached everyone. His bold declaration of  the meaninglessness of caste and ritual, the oppression of women, and the absurdity of communal divisions could be understood by all. Needless to say, for authorities his music was something to be wary of. 
 In one of his songs, Lalon challenges the obsession with external appearance by saying, 
 “ They say the body is impure, but where will you live then? ” 
 This line puts emphasis on the concept that the body is a vessel of the divine. Lalon believed that the body, when respected and understood, becomes the means of spiritual realization.  Lalon’s Influence on Bengali Culture and Music Lalon’s songs are revered by countlessly more people who do not belong to the spiritual community; his influence stretches far beyond. Many folk and classical artists have interpreted his songs. Among them is Nobel Laureate Rabindranath Tagore. Tagore was influenced by Lalon's philosophy so much so that he even introduced urban elites and international audiences to Lalon's music. 
 After the abolishment of colonial rule in Bangladesh and West Bengal, Lalon became a symbol of resistance, reformation and cultural identity. His music was a source of motivation and power for Bengalis. During subsequent political unrests, his songs were the glue that united communities and formed  resilience against oppressive authority and government.  
 Epilogue “Everyone asks, ‘What religion does Lalon belong to?’ 
 Lalon says, ‘ I’ve never found the answer .’” Lalon’s songs are still a source of much inspiration for Bengalis and also anyone who is in search of their purpose in this world. He offered us a  journey which is spiritual as well as revolutionary.  
 Lalon Shah  is an icon of Bengali culture who inspired many poets and thinkers who came later. His legacy is not just his songs, it also includes the awareness he invited us to raise for both ourselves and our societies.

Title: Sufism in Bengali Music: Lalon’s Journey to Social and Political Reformation

Excerpt: The mountainous landscape of Kabylia - meaning “Land of Tribes”- is a region that belongs to the Atlas Mountains and spreads along the...
Plain Content: The mountainous landscape of Kabylia - meaning “Land of Tribes”- is a region that belongs to the Atlas Mountains and spreads along the coast of the Mediterranean Sea. With a nurturing sea and a harsh mountain as guardian deities, it is the homeland of the Kabyle people, known for its vibrant culture and traditions. A monumental figure in Kabyle music and Amazigh culture, a singer-songwriter and musician,  who was soon to be referred to as the "King of Amazigh music," was born nearly seven decades ago. This article is dedicated to this musician whose lyrics are nothing short of poetries, whose voice is akin to a calm ocean yet shakes the stern mountain. This is the story of Idir, one of its most cherished ambassadors of Berber or Amazigh music. Idir was born in Aït Yenni, Tizi Ouzou Province, part of former French Algeria, on 25 October 1945 as Hamid Cheriet. Raised in a family that valued tradition, Idir was exposed to the music and oral poetry of his ancestors from a young age. The region of Kabylie is a historically significant area in Algeria. The people have a deep-rooted heritage and not only that, they had to bear the curse of colonialism and political repression. Their language and culture were marginalized by the predominantly Arab culture of the Algerian government. Both the nourishing culture and more than a century-long struggle against oppression influenced and eventually shaped the artistic vision of Idir. This background, apart from molding his worldview, served as inspiration for his lyrics, which often reflected the themes of identity, nostalgia, and social issues. Idir, oblivious to what his fate had in reserve for him, pursued studying geology and to establish his career path, he worked in an oil and gas field. In this petroleum field, his musical proficiency didn't go unnoticed. Despite his nonchalance towards becoming a professional artist, in 1973, he substituted for Nouara, an Algerian singer, on Radio Algeria. He performed  "A Vava Inouva", a lullaby composed by Idir with Ben Mohamed  incorporating the "rich oral traditions" of his Amazigh culture and was inspired by a traditional story about “a young girl trying to save her father from danger.”  This song was written for Nouara, but she refused. Left with no other choice, Idir interpreted it himself, sang it on the radio, and went on with his involuntary draft for military service, unaware of the aftermath of his song. The lullaby song was an immediate success. Moreover, it might arguably be the best-known song in the Kabyle language internationally as well as an unprecedented commercial hit. Here, it should be mentioned why Idir chose this  stage name during his performance of  "A Vava Inouva.” During the epidemics in Algeria, there were neither doctors nor hospitals for medical care. There were times when children were dying as soon as they were born. In hope for their children’s survival through the epidemics, parents named them “Idir,” a kabyle name which means “He lives.” After returning from his mandatory military service, he was surprised by the success and praise his song had received. He realized the extent of the power that his music held and the responsibility of becoming the voice of his people and his cultural heritage that he was bestowed upon. During this time, Idir was contacted by the record company Pathé Marconi as well, and he knew what he had to do. With a more refined sense of the journey he had to embark on, in 1975, he set out for France to work on his debut album- A Vava Inouva. On this album, we can hear his signature sound featuring traditional Kabylian flute and darbouka. In Idir’s own words, the title song, “A Vava Inouva”  had chosen him. Maybe it really did, considering the success it brought him and how it was translated into seven languages.  Following his sophomore album  Ay Arrac Nneɣ in 1979, Idir took a long hiatus from music. He felt unsatisfied with the show-biz and his stage performances. And for more than a decade, all he did was perform for a few recitals. But, in 1991 he released a compilation album with 17 tracks from his previous albums. This was named A Vava Inouva, the same as his debut album and, of course, features his greatest song “A Vava Inouva”. This album also features other successful songs, such as "Azwaw", "Zwit Rwit", "Ssendu" and "Cfiy".  The Amazigh song  "Zwit Rwit" has an Arabic version,  covered by prominent Algerian Rai singer Cheb Khaled. Idir’s true comeback to the music scene occurred when he released a new album Les Chasseurs de lumières.  This album had characteristic compositional traits like the utilization of the derbouka, flute, and guitar and poetic lyrics on love, freedom, and exile. But, it also had a modernized sense of composing which is evident from the incorporation of synthesizers. After the release of this record, he became a revered figure who advocated the Kabyle and Berber cultures through his form of art. In his 2007 album, La France des Couleurs ( meaning “France of Colors"), Idir contemplated the diversity of the identity of all French people, multiculturalism, and immigration. After releasing his final album, Ici et Ailleurs (meaning "Here and Elsewhere"), he returned to his native Algeria.  Idir started performing in his homeland with renewed vigor after being practically exiled for 38 years. His concerts were flooded with his native fans. His concerts were much more than mere entertainment for his admirers, these were his way of supporting different causes. He shared a stage with his friend, singer Khaled, in a concert for peace, freedom, and tolerance. Idir participated in a concert held in memory of the Kabyle singer Lounès Matoub, who, along with Idir, was considered as an unstoppable force against the oppression of the Kabyle people. Adhering to his pride in his national identity, he organized a fund-raising concert in support of the population in Kabylie amidst the anti-government riots that were taking place in the predominantly Berber region. In retrospect, Idir had always been a cultural ambassador for the Kabyle people.  He has inspired a new generation of musicians to explore their heritage and encouraged them to take pride in their identity and tradition. He was a valiant human being who instilled the idea of preserving the diversity of culture and stood against the insidious rush of our society to homogenize the whole world and turn it into a gray soup of modernity. Without a shred of doubt, he is the true  “King of Amazigh.”

Title: Idir - The Poet of the Mountains

Excerpt: Drums of Defiance: The Djembe’s Role in West Africa’s Fight for Freedom
Plain Content: The djembe, a traditional West African drum, is a perdurable musical instrument known for its powerful and sophisticated sound. Shouldering the burden of possibly a millennium-long history, this instrument remains as a tightly knit rope that ties numerous cultures from faraway lands to their customs and heritage. Born from the hands of skilled blacksmiths and shaped by a chain of shifts in traditional values, with each strike, it speaks a language beyond translation, yet retains its ability to call people together in joy, in mourning, and in celebration.  The Origins of the Djembe The origin of the djembe dates back to 1230 AD, when the Mali Empire ruled millions of people from nearly every ethnic group in West Africa. Geographically, what remains of that empire today is the parts divided among the modern-day countries of Guinea, Mali, Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast, Gambia, and Senegal. It is generally believed that the djembe originated from the Mandinka caste of blacksmiths, known as “Numu“ of the Mali Empire. Also, the way the Numu people migrated during the first millennium AD explains the wide dispersion of the djembe drum throughout West Africa. The name "djembe" is quite interesting. It is derived from a phrase of the Mandinka language, "Anke dje, anke be," which literally means or translates to "everyone, gather together in peace." This phrase beautifully reflects what purpose the drum was intended to serve — bringing people together. So, naturally, the djembe was an integral element of communal gatherings, from births, harvest festivals, and weddings to funerals. This membranophone was also linked to the spiritual ceremonies, a fact that emphasizes its sacred role in West African society. The djembe has a goblet-shaped body or shell carved of hardwood and untreated rawhide is commonly used to make a drumhead. The tension in this animal skin produces an unusually loud sound for its size. Djembe and Communities  The djembe, both in the past and at present, plays a multifaceted role in the West African community in addition to being a musical instrument. The djembe's music summons people to significant gatherings, festivities, and group projects in many villages. The drum's rhythms promote harmony and a feeling of purpose.  Community gatherings often feature music sessions, and djembe remains at the center of it, where everyone, regardless of age or skill level, can participate. These gatherings are entertaining for sure, but simultaneously serve as a means of communication and collaboration and, in doing so, reinforce their collective identity. As a result of having such ties to a culture, learning to play the djembe requires more than just mastering rhythms; a djembefola (who plays djembe) must have a well-rounded understanding of the historical and cultural contexts of the music. Djembe & the Fate of West Africa Anyone who has familiarized themselves with the history of West Africa is certainly aware of the periods of immense struggle, including colonization, slavery, and the degradation of traditional cultures. Incessant aggression against their core values has forced them to build resistance. Djembe has been crucial in their pursuit of preserving their roots and identities. The Slave Trade During the transatlantic slave trade, millions of West Africans were forcibly taken from their homelands and transported to the Americas. They were often prohibited from practicing their traditional customs, which, of course, included music. They wanted to play music, but plantation owners banned all percussion instruments as they thought that drums might be used for secret communication. Separating slaves from their culture was a deliberate effort to make them more subservient. Fortunately, the rhythms and techniques of the djembe survived in such a predicament. Many instruments that were developed further down the line inherited the legacy of the djembe. In this way, the djembe remained a silent presence in the struggle for freedom. The Djembe and the Anti-Colonial Struggle  The driving force behind the slave trade was colonialism. The need for labor in European colonies of the Americas and the Caribbean led to the transatlantic slave trade and the macabre chronicles of oppression that followed.  As traditional practices, including drumming and dancing, were getting banned, African communities stood sternly against it and refused to let their culture die. With the progression of their resistance, the djembe was turning into a sharp tool that would end up aiding in curving out the path for freedom.  A Symbol of Post-Independence Identity The djembe's popularity skyrocketed in a post-independence cultural renaissance in the mid-1950s when African countries were reclaiming their long sought independence. In countries like Mali, Senegal, and Guinea, the djembe was, and still is, the emblem of African unity and pride.  However, uprooting the pillars of oppression in one's own land is different from breaking out of the insidious psychological barriers of colonialism in one's mind. Post-colonial society often finds it difficult to bring down such suffocating walls of the lingering influence of the past. Traditional arts play an essential role in asserting the uniqueness of a culture and the identity of its people. For West Africa, the mighty djembe took up this responsibility.  The Djembe in Modern-Day From the Black Lives Matter to grassroots movements across Africa, one of the unchanged elements is the djembe. How the djembe continues to resonate with communities or individuals, even today, is a telltale indicator of the unabated relevance of djembe. In as early as the 1950s, the djembe was not known to many beyond Africa, apart from some music enthusiasts or those who grew up with it. Many legendary djembeayers toured around the world and earned reverence for themselves as well as for djembe. One of those pioneers is Fodeba Keita of Guinea, who brought a tour of Les Ballets Africains around the world.  Although European countries were the first to take notice of djembe and it became more popular there, Germany, China and also Japan have seen a new wave of interest in it. The surge of appreciation for the djembe not only points toward a well-deserved recognition but also towards its uncanny ability to blend perfectly with many other styles of traditional music which developed in an entirely different environment. This proves the immaculate reverence that this instrument has accumulated in the preceding eras. Final Words  The djembe is fascinating both in terms of the powerful sound it produces and the history it retains within itself in a cryptic language of its own. The only way to make sense of this language is to willingly immerse oneself in the vibrant, rich, and engrossing tradition of this instrument. It stood for the preservation of culture, heritage, and identity as much as it did against the claws of colonization, slavery, or any other threats. As long as humanity wields the indomitable spirit to rise above any ordeal that crosses its path, the drums of defiance will reverberate throughout the world and resonate with every earthling.

The drum's rhythms promote harmony and a feeling of purpose. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"sczii303","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"khpom304","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Community gatherings often feature music sessions, and djembe remains at the center of it, where everyone, regardless of age or skill level, can participate. These gatherings are entertaining for sure, but simultaneously serve as a means of communication and collaboration and, in doing so, reinforce their collective identity. As a result of having such ties to a culture, learning to play the djembe requires more than just mastering rhythms; a djembefola (who plays djembe) must have a well-rounded understanding of the historical and cultural contexts of the music.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"qbw3c306","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Djembe & the Fate of West Africa","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"2znwa308","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Anyone who has familiarized themselves with the history of West Africa is certainly aware of the periods of immense struggle, including colonization, slavery, and the degradation of traditional cultures. Incessant aggression against their core values has forced them to build resistance. Djembe has been crucial in their pursuit of preserving their roots and identities.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"6g7c1310","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Slave Trade","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":2,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"wbzpv312","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"During the transatlantic slave trade, millions of West Africans were forcibly taken from their homelands and transported to the Americas. They were often prohibited from practicing their traditional customs, which, of course, included music. They wanted to play music, but plantation owners banned all percussion instruments as they thought that drums might be used for secret communication. Separating slaves from their culture was a deliberate effort to make them more subservient.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"39842314","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"yh1mt315","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Fortunately, the rhythms and techniques of the djembe survived in such a predicament. Many instruments that were developed further down the line inherited the legacy of the djembe. In this way, the djembe remained a silent presence in the struggle for freedom.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"aqx63317","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Djembe and the Anti-Colonial Struggle ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":2,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"reo9r319","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The driving force behind the slave trade was colonialism. The need for labor in European colonies of the Americas and the Caribbean led to the transatlantic slave trade and the macabre chronicles of oppression that followed. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"o0hyc321","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"b0sql322","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"As traditional practices, including drumming and dancing, were getting banned, African communities stood sternly against it and refused to let their culture die. With the progression of their resistance, the djembe was turning into a sharp tool that would end up aiding in curving out the path for freedom. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"hlgh8324","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"A Symbol of Post-Independence Identity","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":2,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"2iuyt326","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The djembe's popularity skyrocketed in a post-independence cultural renaissance in the mid-1950s when African countries were reclaiming their long sought independence. In countries like Mali, Senegal, and Guinea, the djembe was, and still is, the emblem of African unity and pride.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"0r0jc328","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"p4wmu329","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":" However, uprooting the pillars of oppression in one's own land is different from breaking out of the insidious psychological barriers of colonialism in one's mind. Post-colonial society often finds it difficult to bring down such suffocating walls of the lingering influence of the past. Traditional arts play an essential role in asserting the uniqueness of a culture and the identity of its people. For West Africa, the mighty djembe took up this responsibility. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"s0fnj331","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"id":"camv4332","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Djembe in Modern-Day","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"90vdb334","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"From the Black Lives Matter to grassroots movements across Africa, one of the unchanged elements is the djembe. How the djembe continues to resonate with communities or individuals, even today, is a telltale indicator of the unabated relevance of djembe.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"hab1c336","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"jv0mm337","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In as early as the 1950s, the djembe was not known to many beyond Africa, apart from some music enthusiasts or those who grew up with it. Many legendary djembeayers toured around the world and earned reverence for themselves as well as for djembe. One of those pioneers is Fodeba Keita of Guinea, who brought a tour of Les Ballets Africains around the world. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ge2o6339","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"t3ib9340","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Although European countries were the first to take notice of djembe and it became more popular there, Germany, China and also Japan have seen a new wave of interest in it. The surge of appreciation for the djembe not only points toward a well-deserved recognition but also towards its uncanny ability to blend perfectly with many other styles of traditional music which developed in an entirely different environment. This proves the immaculate reverence that this instrument has accumulated in the preceding eras.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"style":{},"id":"vl9vy342","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Final Words ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"headingData":{"level":1,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"JUSTIFY"}},"style":{},"id":"bm2dk344","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The djembe is fascinating both in terms of the powerful sound it produces and the history it retains within itself in a cryptic language of its own. The only way to make sense of this language is to willingly immerse oneself in the vibrant, rich, and engrossing tradition of this instrument. It stood for the preservation of culture, heritage, and identity as much as it did against the claws of colonization, slavery, or any other threats. As long as humanity wields the indomitable spirit to rise above any ordeal that crosses its path, the drums of defiance will reverberate throughout the world and resonate with every earthling.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"w3613346","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}}],"documentStyle":{}}
Title: Drums of Defiance: The Djembe’s Role in West Africa’s Fight for Freedom

Excerpt: Born in Sunamganj, Bangladesh, on the shores of the Kalni River, Shah Abdul Karim is a legendary figure in Bengali Baul music. Recognized...
Plain Content: Born in Sunamganj, Bangladesh, on the shores of the Kalni River, Shah Abdul Karim is a legendary figure in Bengali Baul music. Recognized as the Baul Shomrat (Baul King,) Karim's songs echoed from villages of Bangladesh to international stages, putting together an unforgettable image of the simplicity and spirituality of rural Bangla. He wrote more than 1,600 songs during his lifetime, and his profound lyrics won over millions of hearts. Even though many of his compositions have been lost just because they were not documented, his philosophy lives on in the pieces that still inspire and connect people worldwide. On February 5, 1916, in the Sunamganj district's Ujan Dhol village, Shah Abdul Karim was born into a poor family. Being the only son out of six siblings, like most people living in poverty in the villages of Bangladesh he had to adjust to the harsh realities of life at an early age. While he had to work as a herdsman for just Tk 2 to support his family, his early years were filled with hardship. Despite his hardships, music became Karim's haven during long days of handling cattle. Karim first heard the Baul music from his grandfather, Nasibullah who was a wandering mystic. As a result of this early exposure, Karim found his lifelong passion, Music. Which can be heard in his songs, “I don't want anything but music. I sing songs. To convince my heart. But my heart is in the land of the crazies(for music).” The only form of formal education Karim had was during British rule when a night school was established in his village. Unfortunately, after only eight days, the school was shut down due to rumors of World War II conscription. Without access to a traditional school, Karim got his education from nature, its people, and his own experiences. Once in an interview, he expressed, “I am not being boastful. I became more knowledgeable than school-going people with the blessings of peers and murshid (holy man and tutor) and the experiences gifted by the creator. And because of this gift, you love me so much and came to me. There are many more Karims like me who are wandering around. But you came to me.” Despite Karim's unwavering devotion to music, the extremists of the country opposed him. He encountered strong opposition from the villagers too, who called him a "Kafir" for not up music. And took his lyrics as a threat to their beliefs. This is to some extent true as he did not believe in any institutionalized religion. To the threats he responded,  “I won’t promise something I won’t do later. I won’t lie in front of everyone.” Because of his honesty, he lost his house and was forced into exile. Karim left his village and wandered around town before taking sanctuary in Gandha, a village with a strong musical heritage. Despite the social rejection, Karim's exile was a pivotal moment that strengthened his ties to the Baul philosophy. To get him out of his Boula life his parents forced him to marry Kachamala when he was 35. The marriage lasted only for a short period as his love of music took priority over his household duties. Karim demonstrated his dedication to his true love by choosing his art over his family. Aftabunnesa, his second wife, affectionately known as Sorola, became his dearest companion and pillar of support. This is what Karim had to say about Sorola, “She was named Boishakhi. I found her simple-natured and started calling her Shorola(someone who is simple).”  Because of Sorola's caring support, Karim was able to fully focus on his music despite their financial difficulties. She often told him, “If I tie you down with my saree, how will you ever explore the world? And if you don’t go out and meet people, how will you understand life or compose your songs?” He wrote many many songs expressing his love for her. Karim's life was left empty after Sorola passed away in 1987. Karim lived with the pain of her loss for the rest of his life, filled with guilt over not being there for her in her last moments. Even at her funeral, the local imam refused to perform her burial rituals, further demonstrating the social rejection he experienced. Karim went on and performed her funeral prayers himself. Sorola was buried in a room opposite to where he stayed in their home reflecting his deep love and attachment to her. Themes of love, spirituality, and social justice were all woven together in Shah Abdul Karim's music. His Baul philosophy, defended simplicity and humanity while criticizing materialism and religious dogmas. The essence of rural life and the hardships faced by people were encapsulated in his lyrics. Karim’s songs, such as “Gari Cholena Cholena”, “Ami Koolhara Kolonkini”, “Kemone Bulibo Tara”, “Shokhi Tora Prem Koriona”, "Age ki shundor din kataitam" and "Maya lagaise," remain popular with listeners even people who are not into Baul music. Karim’s profound insights into life and spirituality found universal appeal. His ability to express complex emotions in simple yet powerful lyrics solidified his place as a storyteller and philosopher. He received numerous awards filling his rooms. He was also honored with Ekushey Padak in 2001. Upon receiving his honor he spoke, “I received my honor a long time ago. When I was young. At a farmer’s union, Moulana Bhashani patted me and told me that I am a people’s artist.” Karim often came into conflict with fundamentalists because of his commitment to humanity over religious doctrine. His songs, which welcomed spirituality and love, occasionally drew criticism for breaking with conventions. On September 12, 2009, at the age of 93, Karim passed away. His body was laid in state at the Shaheed Minar, where thousands gathered to pay respect. In his honor, a fleet of boats sailed him to Dhul Gram, his village, where he was buried next to Sorola. His songs were collected in six books: Aftab Sangeet, Gano Sangeet, Kalnir Dhew, Dholmela, Bhatir Chithi, and Kalnir Kooley. The Bangla Academy translated 10 of his songs into English, to expand his legacy to a global audience.  Shah Abdul Karim's songs are still performed by traditional Bauls across Bangladesh and West Bengal, maintaining authenticity. Artists from genres other than Bauls such as Habib Wahid, Arifin Rumey, Kaya, and Helal have transformed his songs for modern listeners. ensuring that his legacy is embraced by both the younger and older generations.  Reminding us of the importance of love, spirituality, and humanity in a world consumed by materialism and division.

In his honor, a fleet of boats sailed him to Dhul Gram, his village, where he was buried next to Sorola.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"dhhig684","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"4v2gy685","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"His songs were collected in six books: Aftab Sangeet, Gano Sangeet, Kalnir Dhew, Dholmela, Bhatir Chithi, and Kalnir Kooley. The Bangla Academy translated 10 of his songs into English, to expand his legacy to a global audience. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3rx0p687","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"bs4b7688","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Shah Abdul Karim's songs are still performed by traditional Bauls across Bangladesh and West Bengal, maintaining authenticity. Artists from genres other than Bauls such as Habib Wahid, Arifin Rumey, Kaya, and Helal have transformed his songs for modern listeners. ensuring that his legacy is embraced by both the younger and older generations.  Reminding us of the importance of love, spirituality, and humanity in a world consumed by materialism and division.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2025-01-04T21:05:05.096Z","updatedTimestamp":"2025-01-04T21:05:05.096Z","id":"9fce6762-31a2-4fec-8682-534fee1f2bd8"},"documentStyle":{}}
Title: Shah Abdul Karim: Melody of Love, Spirituality, and Unity

Excerpt: Fela Anikulapo Kuti is a Nigerian artist and political activist. He is revered as the father of Afrobeat and throughout his life, he has...
Plain Content: Fela Anikulapo Kuti is a Nigerian artist and political activist. He is revered as the father of Afrobeat and throughout his life, he has been a musical and cultural revolutionary figure. Fela's music and his voice of resistance have surpassed the boundaries of his homeland to become a global symbol. A fleeting glance over his life and work is enough to draw the conclusion that he had an unfathomable power to wield music as a weapon against dilapidated social structure and unjust political arbitrariness. This article sheds light on a mere slice of Fela Kuti's life who has changed the course of world music and political reformation. Born on October 15, 1938, in Abeokuta, Nigeria, as Olufela Olusegun Oludotun Ransome-Kuti but this Pan-Africanist is known to the masses as Fela Anikulapo Kuti or Fela Kuti. He hails from an upper-middle-class Nigerian family with his mother Chief Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti, and father Israel Oludotun Ransome-Kuti. While growing up, having an anti-colonial feminist mother along with a minister and principal father, both of whom played active roles in the anti-colonial movement in Nigeria, Fela was bound to develop an innate sense of justice and freedom. Such an environment of intellectual and political exposure imparted to him the ability to develop his own worldview. In 1958, Fela moved to London to study medicine, which was what his parents wished for him. Despite the initial acceptance of his parents' wish, he couldn't refuse his call to music. Eventually, leaving medicine behind, started his pursuit of music. Fela admitted himself to the Trinity College of Music, and there he formed his first band, Koola Lobitos. Their music blended jazz with highlife, a popular West African music genre. This was his first step into the contemporary music scene and also the beginning of his extensive experimentation in search of his own sound staying true to his African roots. Encouraged by his father, Fela Kuti learned to play multiple instruments like saxophone, piano, trumpet, and occasionally drums. He grew up with his father's belief, "Education is not complete without the knowledge of music," and this mindset was always with him in his pursuit of generic sound. Yet, his parents were not in the same boat as him when it came to his choice of music. His mother wanted him to play music that everyone could understand, not jazz. And here, we get a glimpse of who Fela truly is as a musician, and as an individual. He could have achieved mainstream success by making mainstream music. But he almost didn't care, commercial success was not what he sought. He sought Groove. The Intricate structure of his songs and the usual length of each track were his declaration of artistic freedom. By virtue of this stubbornness, at the peak of his career, he was known as one of Africa's most "challenging and charismatic music performers". The crucial breakthrough in his career occurred in the late 1960s. Fela Kuti successfully combined traditional African music with Jazz, funk, and highlife and developed Afrobeat. As a genre, Afrobeat is characterized by its complex polyrhythms, extended instrumental jams, and chanted vocals. In the later years, many artists and bands adopted the ideas of Afrobeat and carried on the legacy left by Fela. Parallel to his relentless musical endeavor another central motif of his life was being nurtured in him as well. Before his Afrobeat era, when he returned to Nigeria, Fela returned with a renewed sense of purpose. In 1969, Fela spent ten months in Los Angeles with his band. There he came across the Black Power movement. The Black Power movement flourished in the 1960s and 1970s and this left a profound impact on Fela when he witnessed the Civil rights struggle in the US. This is where he encountered James Brown, an American singer, dancer, and an important American influence on Kuti's musical style. Upon returning to Nigeria, his music became a powerful tool for his political activism. He reformed the band and changed its name. The tone in his music shifted and the lyrics spoke of socio-political issues of both Nigeria and Africa. His voice of resistance reverberated beyond Africa. His stern position against the corruption of Nigerian government officials drew both amicable and inimical attention to him. Corruption, oppression, colonialism, and many other relevant issues were at the core of his music. Songs like 'Zombie,' 'Shakara,' and 'Sorrow, Tears, and Blood' are still relevant in 21st-century Africa. In the '70s, Fela formed the Kalakuta Republic. It served as his recording studio and a place for his family. This accommodated many people who were associated with the band in one way or the other. Kalakuta was not just a residence; it was a cultural and political hub free of any political restraints. In this place, Fela could express his ideas freely and challenge the autocracy.  Fela took a bold step and declared the Kalakuta Republic as an independent state. Members of this community faced frequent raids, as the government wasn't pleased with Fela's activism and the growing popularity of his music. Being outspoken and defiant to the Nigerian authorities had already made him a target. This resulted in clashes between Fela and the governing regime of Nigeria. The situation got out of hand when 1000 soldiers raided his place, beat Fela and they even threw Fela's mother out of the window. They burned the place down along with his instruments and recordings. These barbaric actions were taken in response to Fela's album Zombie (1977) where he had criticized Nigerian military methods. Fela Kuti was undeterred through all these acts of violence against him. He always had his weapons - his voice, his music. His albums were grabbing mass attention and enraging the government in the process. Each of his albums throughout the 1980s and 1990s, was a mockery of contemporary political issues in Fela's own characteristic blend of wit, anger, and musical brilliance. Fela Kuti's life tells a story of the inherent power of music and how it can bring in social change. His incessant activism and groundbreaking musical innovations have left a timeless mark on the world. Fela realized the bigger picture of life, music, and politics. His Afrobeat was a movement; it was a voice for the voiceless and oppressed people of Africa. This is the reason why Fela's legacy will continue among us.
